title: Lessons for Biodiversity Project
text:
Welcome to our webpage!
This website is to help store code for specific lessons, so that the students can easily access the script. Our students will be using the programming language python, so all the scripts will be using that format.

title: About
text: Hi, we are the Biodiversity interns for the school year 2024-2025! Our names are Akira, Mercedes, and Lauren, and we come from a variety of different majors with the goal of teaching K-12 students Data Science. For further information about us, you can look on the biodiversity project webpage.

title: Lessons
text:
In this lesson, we be exploring python for the first time! We will be using this programming software to explore a sonoran crop data set.
Python Website
Activity Worksheet
Powerpoint for activity

title: Lesson_6_Code

title: Lesson_6_Code
text:
Step Two
We have to have import pandas. Pandas is a library in python that allows us to create, load, and adjust data sets.


Show the code
import pandas as pd

species = pd.DataFrame({'species': ['Buffelgrass'] * 4 + 
['Yellow BlueStem'] * 4 + 
['Saguro Cactus'] * 4 + 
['Palo Verde'] *4 + 
['Canyon Towhee'] * 4 + 
['Feral Swine'] * 4 + 
['Bullfrog'] * 4 , 

'populationSize':

[1980,3990,7950,15890,105,295,915,2710,1700,1731,1800,1871,2002,2098,2151,2198,7000,6975,5820,5000,3809,4021,5321,6321,495,705,860,1045],

'speciesType':
['invasive'] * 8 +
['non-invasive'] * 12 +
['invasive'] * 8,

'year': 
[2014,2015,2016,2017,2014,2015,2016,2017,2014,2015,2016,2017,2014,2015,2016,2017,2014,2015,2016,2017,2014,2015,2016,2017,2014,2015,2016,2017]
})




#let's take a look at our dataset
print(species.to_string())

title: Lesson_6_Code
text:
Step 3
Let’s make a graph for the population changes seen in our data set. For visualization, we need to import a new library called matplot. In this library, we can access different types of graphs.

#Before graphing, we should see what type of species we have.
speciesTypes = species['species'].unique()
print(speciesTypes)

['Buffelgrass' 'Yellow BlueStem' 'Saguro Cactus' 'Palo Verde'
 'Canyon Towhee' 'Feral Swine' 'Bullfrog']

title: Lesson_6_Code
section: Now that we know what species to work with…
text:
Now that we know what species to work with…
Let’s pick some species to work with! We need to filter our data, so that we can work with the right data.


Show the code
#we will now pick three species in our dataset
species_one = 'Buffelgrass'
species_two = 'Yellow BlueStem'
species_three = 'Saguro Cactus'

#since we are working with alot of data
#we have to filter it to the data we want
species_copy = species.copy()

filtered_data = species_copy[species_copy['species'] == species_one].copy()

filtered_data_2 = species_copy[species_copy['species'] == species_two].copy()

filtered_data_3 = species_copy[species_copy['species'] == species_three].copy()

# let's check if we selected the right data
print(filtered_data.head())
#
print('-------------------------------------------------------------------')
print(filtered_data_2.head())
print('-------------------------------------------------------------------')
print(filtered_data_3.head())
print('-------------------------------------------------------------------')


       species  populationSize speciesType  year
0  Buffelgrass            1980    invasive  2014
1  Buffelgrass            3990    invasive  2015
2  Buffelgrass            7950    invasive  2016
3  Buffelgrass           15890    invasive  2017
-------------------------------------------------------------------
           species  populationSize speciesType  year
4  Yellow BlueStem             105    invasive  2014

6  Yellow BlueStem             915    invasive  2016
7  Yellow BlueStem            2710    invasive  2017

title: Lesson_6_Code
section: Our filtered data set matches what species we selected. Let’s make a bar chart!
text:
Our filtered data set matches what species we selected. Let’s make a bar chart!


Show the code
#importing visualization library
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

fig, ax = plt.subplots()

filtered_data.plot.bar(x = 'species', y = 'populationSize',  rot = 0 , ax =ax, color ='blue', label = 'Buffelgrass')

filtered_data_2.plot.bar(x = 'species', y = 'populationSize',  rot = 0, ax = ax, color ='red', label = 'Yellow Bluestem')

filtered_data_3.plot.bar(x = 'year', y = 'populationSize',  rot = 0, ax = ax, color ='green', label ='Saguaro Catcus')


#let's add labels to our graph
ax.set_xlabel('Year')
ax.set_ylabel('Population Size')
ax.set_title('Population Size Over Time')


Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Population Size Over Time')

title: Lesson_6_Code
text:
Step 4
We are going to now look at two species, Feral Swine (an invasive species) and Canyon Towhee (a native species), and see how these populations change over time.

title: Lesson_6_Code
text:
Let’s graph these populations…


Show the code
# Define the two species we want to compare
swine = 'Feral Swine'
bird = 'Canyon Towhee'

# Filter the data for the two species
swine_data = species[species['species'] == swine].copy()
bird_data = species[species['species'] == bird].copy()


# Visualize the data as a line plot
fig, ax2 = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))

# Plot Feral Swine population
ax2.plot(swine_data['year'], swine_data['populationSize'],
         color='red', linewidth=2, marker='o', label='Feral Swine')

# Plot Canyon Towhee population
ax2.plot(bird_data['year'], bird_data['populationSize'],
         color='blue', linewidth=2, marker='s', label='Canyon Towhee')

# Add labels and title to the plot
ax2.set_xlabel('Year')
ax2.set_ylabel('Population Size')
ax2.set_title('Population Size Over Time: Feral Swine vs Canyon Towhee')

# Add a legend to differentiate between species
ax2.legend(title="Species")

# Show the plot
plt.show()

title: Lesson_6_Code
text:
Background about Feral Swine
Feral swine are opportunistic omnivores, meaning they eat whatever they can find. Their diet is incredibly diverse and includes both plants and animals. They have a strong preference for eggs, especially those of ground-nesting birds and they often destroy these nests to consume eggs. Beyond eggs, feral swine will also prey on small mammals and amphibians. Additionally, feral swine consume a wide range of vegetation, from fruits, nuts, and seeds to grasses and berries, and even raid agricultural crops like corn.
